tags.name: Mandates
tags.description:
# Payment Mandates

Mandates are a payment source.

A Payment Mandate is a single consent, given by a PSU, to authorise repeated payments on a schedule
or ad-hoc basis. Depending on the use case, the PSU may not be required to authorise payments against
an existing mandate.

The consent given for a mandate will always include the same debtor (or remitter) account. Depending on
the type of Mandate, the creditor (or beneficiary) account may or may not always be the same.

## VRP (Sweeping/Commercial)

Variable Recurring Payments (VRP) are an Open Banking specification allowing a PSU to
authorize repeated payments from their bank account to another account they own.

The PSU only needs to give this consent once. Payments against this consent can then be
initiated by a PSP to move funds between accounts with no further input from the PSU.

When establishing this consent, the PSU will agree to certain parameters that will enforce
limits such as how long the consent will be valid for and what maximum value of transfer will be
allowed over the consent lifetime. Other limits can be set for timeframes within this lifetime.

A new VRP Mandate is created by calling `POST /v3/mandates`, using a bearer token.

OpenBanking VRP Mandates require the end user to go through an authorization flow -
the status of the newly created mandate will therefore be `authorization_required`.
The mandate resource will contain a `mandate_token` that can be safely shared with the UI,
where the authorization flow will be taking place.

The UI can use the `mandate_token` to kick off the **authorization journey**.
Authorizing an OpenBanking mandate usually requires multiple **actions**:
  - collect information from the end user (e.g. select a banking institution);
  - redirect to a bank's website or mobile app;
  - etc.

The UI must specify, using `POST /v3/mandates/authorization_flow`, which **actions** it supports.
Configuration parameters can be specified for each action type - e.g. what `return_uri` to
use for a `redirect` step, if "direct return" is enabled (regulated merchant), etc.

After the call to `POST /v3/mandates/authorization_flow`, the mandate status will transition to `authorizing`.
The UI must now inspect the `authorization_flow.actions.next` field in the mandate resource and submit the required
information via `POST /v3/mandates/authorization_flow/actions`.

The mandate might then transition into `authorized`, or stay in `authorizing` with a different next action.

Should the PSU and/or Provider decide to reject the authorization, the mandate status will
transition to `revoked`.

Payments can only be made against a mandate once it has transitioned to `authorized`. Those payments
will then need to fall within the boundaries set by the consent parameters.

Should the PSU and/or Provider decide to reject the authorization, the mandate status will
transition to `revoked`.
